abstract.p: Robert L Belvin letter responds to June 18 article on rise and fall of stocks that have been hyped in online chat rooms; objects to depiction of investment chat rooms as a sort of 'e-Kiwanis Club'

block.p: Re ''Chat-Room Millions, Real-Life Misery''(June 18) which looked at the rise and fall of a stock that had been hyped in chat rooms:
Re ''Chat-Room Millions, Real-Life Misery''(June 18) which looked at the rise and fall of a stock that had been hyped in chat rooms:

The article compared the camaraderie of an investment chat room to an ''e-Kiwanis Club.'' That would be a good analogy if those chat-room inhabitants were dedicated to raising $75 million to eliminate iodine deficiency disorder, a preventable cause of mental retardation (a Kiwanis International worldwide service project), financing a pediatric trauma center at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick (one of our New Jersey projects), donating to projects that help battered women and help families read together (a couple of our local programs) or taking time out of holiday season weekends to ring the bell for the Salvation Army.
If those kinds of activities do not apply, then my organization and other service clubs, like Rotary and the Lions, are done a disservice.
ROBERT J. BELVIN New Brunswick, N.J., June 18
The writer is a member of the Kiwanis Club of New Brunswick.
